titlestmt.title: There is No Natural Religion copy M : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 90KB; 20 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 69KB to 696KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC Libraries
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of There is No Natural Religion, copies A, D, and M, from the British Museum, Houghton Library, and Victoria and Albert Museum respectively. They join copy B, from Yale Center for British Art, copy C, from the Library of Congress, and copies G1-2 and L, from the Morgan Library and Museum. The Archive now has all seven extant copies of this illuminated book, making There is No Natural Religion the sixth illuminated book with its entire publishing history reproduced in the Archive, joining The Song of Los, Milton a Poem, All Religions are One, The Book of Ahania, and The Book of Los. The Archive will add The Marriage of Heaven and Hell to the list later this year. There is No Natural Religion was composed and executed in 1788, shortly after All Religions are One. These were Blake's first works in illuminated printing, though no copy of either work survives from this date. Blake composed twenty plates for There is No Natural Religion plates in two antithetical sets (a and b series). Only copy L consists exclusively of the ten b series of plates. The other twelve recorded copies of this book share impressions of the same group of either eight or twelve plates, which appeared to be merely incomplete sets of impressions until it was discovered that six of these copies were 19th-century reproductions. Once the inauthentic impressions were weeded out, it became apparent that what remained was Blake's selection of a and b plates for an abridged version of the work printed around 1794.
With the publication of There is No Natural Religion copies A, D, and M, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of 95 copies of Blake's nineteen illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. New protocols for transcription, which produce improved accuracy and fuller documentation in editors' notes, have been applied to all copies of There is No Natural Religion in the Archive. With the Archive's Compare feature, users can easily juxtapose multiple impressions of any plate across all or selected copies of this or any of the other illuminated books and, with the Virtual Lightbox, users can examine any images in the Archive, as well as crop, zoom, and juxtapose them for close study.
In addition to illuminated books, the Archive contains many important manuscripts and series of engravings, sketches, and water color drawings, including Blake's illustrations to Thomas Gray's Poems, water color and engraved illustrations to Dante's Divine Comedy, the large color printed drawings of 1795 and c. 1805, the Linnell and Butts sets of the Book of Job water colors and the sketchbook containing drawings for the engraved illustrations to the Book of Job, the water color illustrations to Robert Blair's The Grave, and all nine of Blake's water color series illustrating the poetry of John Milton.
In December 2014, the Archive launched a new wing, which contains searchable HTML and PDF editions of thirty-nine past issues of Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly published from 2000 through 2009. PDF versions present the journal as originally published, but the HTML versions are re-implemented with many full-color images from the Blake Archive, making it possible for users to link directly to those works that have been published in the Archive.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

changestmt.change: This work has been revised to include corrections and improvements (to the textual transcriptions and editors' notes for consistency, accuracy, and visual presentation) that were not reflected in the original XML conversion.
changestmt.respstmt: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Technical Editor: William Shaw Project Manager: William Shaw Conversion: William Shaw; Aziza Technology Associates Project Assistants: Kate Attkisson, Kit Curtin, Christopher N. objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist "The Author & Printer W Blake" is etched in reverse at the bottom of plate 1. In this copy, however, the lettering is obscured by coloring.

imprint.publisher: William BlakeBlake is named as the printer on the frontispiece, but he is also the "publisher."
imprint.pubplace: London The place of publication is not given in the work, but Blake was living in London at the time of its composition and etching. He was living in the London suburb of Lambeth when he printed this copy.

objinfo.objorder: Bentley Plates a1-a6, a8-a9, b4, b12There is no evidence that the plates were ever bound. The order given here is the standard one for copies printed in 1794. Bentley Plates a7 and b3 originally may have been included, as in other copies printed c. 1794, but removed or lost at a later date (see the note on Provenance, below).
objinfo.objsize: Ranging between 4.7 x 3.5 cm. and 6.1 x 4.6 cm.
objinfo.medium: relief etching with touches of white-line etching on some plates
objinfo.printingstyle: relief, with rudimentary color printing on Objects 5-9
objinfo.etchednumbers: noneThe etched numbers (I-III, V-VI, II) on Objects 4-9 are headings, not plate numbers.

provenance.name: Victoria and Albert Museum
provenance.note: Possibly acquired directly from Blake by Charles Augustus Tulk (1786-1849); probably by inheritance to "Mrs. Tulk" (wife or daughter-in-law of C. A. Tulk?), in whose collection the work is recorded in the 1876 *Exhibition of the Works of William Blake*, Burlington Fine Arts Club, nos. 304-06, described as containing 11 prints, and thus possibly including Bentley Plate a7 or Bentley Plate b3; probably by inheritance through members of the Tulk family concluding with John A. Tulk, who bequeathed the work to the Victoria and Albert Museum in 1956.

desc.objtitle:
There is No Natural Religion,
Object 1 (Bentley a1, Erdman a1, Keynes a2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two youthful males, both nude and with curly hair, stand on the right. The youth furthest to the right appears to have his left arm raised and may have his left hand resting on the tree trunk near the right margin. The youth furthest to the left holds a shepherd's crook in his right hand. On the left is a seated couple; both the old man, with a long beard, and the woman wear gowns. The man appears to be seated on a fluted pillar. The woman may be wearing drapery (a scarf?) over her head. Another tree stands along the left margin; its branches and leaves form a canopy over the seated figures. Mountains dominate the distant landscape.

component.illusobjdesc: A youthful male, nude and with curly hair, stands on the right. He appears to have his left arm raised, perhaps with his left hand resting on or holding the tree trunk near the right margin. His right arm is at his side. His body suggests a contrapposto posture. He looks down and to the left.

A youthful male, nude and with curly hair, stands to the left of another such figure. He holds a shepherd's crook in his right hand. Both arms are at his side. His face is partly turned to the right; he may be looking at his companion.

An old, bearded man with long hair sits on a fluted pillar. He wears a long gown and looks to the right. His right arm is slightly bent and may rest on the pillar that he is seated on; his left arm appears to rest on his knee.
A woman sits behind and to the right of the old bearded man. She wears a gown and has drapery (a scarf?) over her head. Her left arm rests at her side. Her face is partly turned to the right.
A tree stands on the right. Its branches and perhaps some leaves spread out near the top of the plate.
A tree stands on the left. Its branches and leaves form a canopy at the top of the plate.
The old, bearded man on the left sits on what appears to be a fluted pillar.
The landscape background is dominated by two ranges of hills or mountains, perhaps marked with indeterminate vegetation.

lg.l: The Author & Printer W BlakeIn reverse lettering, obscured by hand coloring.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 2 (Bentley a2, Erdman a2, Keynes a1)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The Gothic structure of spires and arches filling most of the plate may be a church facade, a church portal, a church window, or an imaginative variation on a tomb canopy of the sort Blake saw (and probably drew) in Westminster Abbey during his apprentice years. The tracery includes at least seven human figures; the largest, upper center, may be the Virgin Mary holding the Christ child. She is flanked on each side by two praying figures. On each side of the design, between sets of spires, are a pair of standing figures, one arranged above the other. Perhaps we are to think of all these figures as statues in stone. The words of the title are incorporated into the design.

component.illusobjdesc: The Gothic structure of spires and arches filling most of the plate may be a church facade, a church portal, the tracery of a church window, or an imaginative variation on a tomb canopy of the sort Blake saw (and probably drew) in Westminster Abbey during his apprentice years. Perhaps were are to think of this architectural confection as being built of stone.

The largest figure in the design stands above the title word "THERE" (line 1). The figure appears to be gowned and may be holding a small child or baby in (her?) left arm. If so, this figure group suggests the Virgin Mary and the Christ child. Given the context, this may be a statue in stone.
The figure standing above title word "THERE" may be holding a baby or small child. If so, then this may be the Virgin Mary and the Christ child. Given the context, this may be a statue in stone.

A gowned figure, apparently with hands together in prayer and looking up and to the right, stands above the first two letters of the title word "THERE" (line 1). Given the context, this may be a statue in stone.

A gowned figure, apparently with hands together in prayer and looking to the left, stands or kneels above the final letter of the title word "THERE" (line 1). Given the context, this may be a statue in stone.

A small gowned figure stands rigidly among the Gothic tracery left of "THERE" in the title inscription (line 1). Given the setting, this may be a saint; the architectural context suggests that this is a statue in stone.

A small gowned figure stands rigidly among the Gothic tracery left of "RELIGION" in the title inscription (line 4). The figure's right arm may be raised, bent at the elbow before his/her chest. Given the setting, this may be a saint; the architectural context suggests that this is a statue in stone.

A small gowned figure stands rigidly among the Gothic tracery right of "NO" in the title inscription (line 2). Given the setting, this may be a saint; the architectural context suggests that this is a statue in stone.

A small gowned figure stands rigidly among the Gothic tracery right of "RELIGION" in the title inscription (line 4). His/her arms appear to be at his/her side. Given the setting, this may be a saint; the architectural context suggests that this is a statue in stone.
The title words are incorporated within the design. Perhaps we are to think of the words as inscribed in stone or on a door.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 3 (Bentley a3, Erdman a3, Keynes a3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The center of the design is dominated by a seated figure, probably female, wearing a long gown. Her legs are crossed and she holds a book or tablet on her right knee and may be writing or drawing on it with her left hand. She appears to be looking up and to the left. On the right is a much smaller standing figure, probably a young girl. She is gowned and may be holding a book or piece of paper from which she reads. On the left is a figure—perhaps a young boy—reclining on the ground but with his torso propped up on his left elbow. He looks down and may be reading or writing in a book. There are two trees near the right margin and one or two near the left margin. Green coloring on the ground suggests grass and possibly hills in the background. Dark shadows fall to the right of the trees and figures. The design would seem to relate to the theme of "Education" (line 3) in the text.

component.illusobjdesc: A seated and gowned figure, probably female, holds a book or tablet on her prominent right knee and may be writing or drawing on it with her left hand. Her legs are crossed and her upper body is slightly twisted to the right. She appears to be looking up and to the left.
A gowned figure, perhaps a young girl, stands right of the larger, seated figure. She looks down and to the left and perhaps reads in a book or a piece of paper she holds in her hands.

A figure, perhaps a young boy, reclines on the ground left of the larger seated figure. His torso is propped up on his left elbow. He looks down and may be reading or writing (with his right hand) in a book.

The right-most and central figures in the lower area of the design hold books or tablets. The figure on the right holds a book or piece of paper. The figure on the left may be looking down and reading in a book.
Two trees, with indications of branches and leaves, grow near the right margin.
One or two trees grow near the left margin. Branches on the right bear slight indications of leaves.
Green coloring on the ground suggests grass and possibly hills in the background.
Dark shadows fall to the right of the trees and figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several representational images, all difficult to make out in this copy, hover around or on the letters of the heading ("The Argument," line 1). These are, from left to right, a figure, probably winged and thus perhaps an angel, hovering above the space between the two words; a figure standing but leaning against the left diagonal of the "A" and with one arm reaching toward the hovering figure (who may be reaching down to him); a figure right of the right diagonal of the "A," probably reaching up and to the right toward a bird hovering above the "u" and "m." It is unclear whether we are viewing the figures on the "A" from the front or the back. The first and last letters of the heading terminate in vine-like decorations, as do many other letters in the text below. Other vines, one with a single loop, extend between the heading and the first line of text.

component.illusobjdesc: A poorly printed figure, winged and thus perhaps an angel, hovers between the two words of the heading (line 1). He or she may be looking and reaching down toward the figure just below and to the right.

A figure stands but leans against the left diagonal of the "A" (line 1) and reaches with one arm toward the hovering figure (who may be reaching down to him). It is unclear whether we are seeing the figure from the front or the back.

A figure stands just right of the second diagonal of the "A" in "Argument" (line 1). It is unclear whether we are seeing the figure from the front or the back. His or her arm on the right reaches up and to the right toward the bird. The figure's arm on the left may also be raised horizontally or at 135 degrees to hold onto the letter.

A bird with extended wings flies above the "u" and "m" of "Argument" (line 1). The direction of its flight is unclear, but the long extensions both right and left suggest a long neck (hence, a swan, crane, or stork?) and a long tail.
The ends of the "T" of "The" in the heading (line 1) on the far left terminate in vine-like decorations.
The ends of the "t" of "Argument" in the heading (line 1) terminate in vine-like decorations.
Vines, one with a single loop, extend between the heading and the first line of text.

The final letter of "Education" (line 3), the final letters of "Naturally" and "only" (line 4), and the first letter of "Sense" (line 5) bear vine-like extensions. The first of these includes at least one loop.

lg.l: Man has no notion of moral
Naturally he is only a natu-

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 4 (Bentley a4, Erdman a4, Keynes a4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude old man leans heavily on a large staff or walking stick and looks down at a dog lying on the ground. The man's long beard cascades next to the staff. The background landscape includes a hill and a clump of trees on the left. A tree grows near the right margin in the foreground. One branch forms a canopy over the old man; another branch climbs along the right margin. A vine spirals around the trunk of the tree and the branch near the upper right margin. This vine continues horizontally along the top of the plate. At the vine's end, top left, sits a small human figure or a perched bird. There may be two birds, or bird-like sprigs of vegetation, just left and right of the heading number ("I," line 1).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude old man leans heavily on a staff or walking stick. He faces left and looks down at a dog lying on the ground. The man's long beard cascades next to the staff. His left arm is bent at the elbow, the forearm extended upward along the staff.
A very small figure sits, facing left, on a vine left of the heading number (line 1). Alternatively, this could be a perched bird.
A dog lies on the ground, front legs spread apart. He faces right and looks up to the old man on the right.
The very small form left of the seated figure may be a flying bird with wings spread.
Forms just left and right of the heading number ("I," line 1) might be flying birds rather than part of the vegetation.
A tree grows near the right margin. One of its branches, bearing leaves, arches above the old man and dog. Another branch curves upward along the right margin.
A vine spirals around the trunk of the tree and its branch near the right margin. The vine continues horizontally along the top margin of the plate, where it may bear a few leaves.
A clump of trees fills the landscape background on the left.
A low hill fills the landscape to the right and left of the old man. Given the distance and perspective, this hill rises between his knees and hips.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 5 (Bentley a5, Erdman a5, Keynes a5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A woman, with long or medium-length hair and wearing a long gown, kneels on the ground. She looks down and to the right at a young child she holds around the waist with her extended right arm and hand (left arm not pictured). The child, also kneeling and facing right, is probably male; there are no clear indications of clothing. He extends his arms horizontally toward a small bird near the right margin. These motifs may relate to the theme of "desires" first raised textually on plate 7 (line 2). The background, right of the woman and above the child, is filled with a clump of trees. A large, leafless tree grows up the left margin and spreads a branch between the heading number ("II," line 1) and the first line of text.

component.illusobjdesc: A woman, with long or medium-length hair and wearing a long gown, kneels on the ground. She looks down and to the right at a young child she holds around the waist with her extended right arm and hand (left arm not pictured).

A young child, probably male and with no clear indications of clothing, kneels on the ground and faces to the right. His hair may be curly. While being held by a woman on the left, the child reaches, arms extended horizontally, toward a small bird near the right margin. The fingers of both hands are spread apart.
A bird flies from the grasp of a child.
The landscape background is filled with trees.
A leafless tree grows up the left margin. One if its branches extends between the heading number ("II," line 1) and the first line of text.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 6 (Bentley a6, Erdman a6, Keynes a6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A man, with curly hair and beard, sits on the ground. He is facing to the left and reaching with both arms in the same direction. His legs are extended horizontally to the left and he may be holding his knees. A winged putto, visible from the waist up, appears behind the seated man's legs. This second figure looks to the right and reaches toward, and perhaps touches, the seated man's right shoulder with his left hand. The putto's right arm is raised, with one finger of his right hand pointing heavenward. This gesture, and simply the winged child himself, may indicate the spiritual perceptions not available to the "3 senses" (line 3). Neither figure shows any clear indications of clothing, though the man may be wearing a gown of some sort. A slender tree or vine, intertwined with a second vine, grows up the right margin and extends in loops horizontally above and below the heading number ("III," line 3) and terminates in three spirals. There may be some plants left of the putto, lower left.

component.illusobjdesc: A man, with curly hair and beard, sits on the ground. He is facing to the left, with legs extended in the same direction, and reaching with both arms to the left. He may be holding his knees. There are no clear indications of any clothing, though he may be wearing a gown of some sort. The fingers of his left hand are spread apart slightly.

A winged putto, seen from the waist up, appears behind the legs of the seated man. The putto's left arm is extended horizontally; his left hand reaches toward, and may touch, the right shoulder of the seated man. The putto's right arm is raised and a finger on his right hand points heavenward. There are no clear indications of clothing.
A slender tree or vine, intertwined with a second vine, grows up the right margin and extends in loops horizontally above and below the heading number ("III," line 1) and terminates in three spirals.
A vine is intertwined around the tree or vine growing up the right margin. This second vine seems to end in the top right corner; the larger tree or vine extends horizontally to the left margin.
There may be some plants left of the putto, lower left.

lg.l: -m nts none could de-In copy M, the "e" in "-ments" did not print.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 7 (Bentley a8, Erdman a8, Keynes a8)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A boy with curly hair strides, right foot forward, back and to the left. He wears knee-length breeches and perhaps a shirt. With arms extended horizontally to the left and fingers spread open on at least his left hand, he reaches toward a duck or swan floating on a small body of water (perhaps a river or lake). The boy's gestures suggest the theme of "Mans desires" in the text (line 2). A tree, with an intertwined vine, grows up the left margin. One of the tree's branches, perhaps bearing a few spiky leaves, arches over the heading number and text at the top of the plate. A dark shadow extends along the ground from the base of the tree on the left to the boy's feet on the right.

component.illusobjdesc: A boy with short, curly hair strides, right foot forward, back and to the left. He wears knee-length breeches and perhaps a shirt. With arms extended horizontally to the left and fingers spread open on at least his left hand, he reaches toward a duck or swan on the left.
A duck or swan floats on a small body of water, perhaps a lake or river. The bird faces to the right.
A tree grows up the left margin of the plate. One of its branches, bearing a few spiky leaves, arches over the heading number and text at the top of the plate.
A vine is entwined around the lower half of the tree near the left margin.
The bird lower left appears to be floating on a small body of water, perhaps a lake or river.
A dark shadow extends along the ground from the base of the tree on the left to the boy's feet on the right.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 8 (Bentley a9, Erdman a9, Keynes a9)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, reclines on the ground with his legs extended to the left and perhaps crossed. He props up his upper body with his arms. He holds his head in his left hand in a posture traditionally associated with melancholy. There are no clear indications of clothing. He looks down at what may be a book held by his right forearm and hand. The long, spiky leaves of two plants, or exceptionally long grasses, arch over his head from both the right and left sides of the plate. A tree grows up the right margin; its branches and leaves extend horizontally along the top of the plate. A vine is entwined around the tree's trunk. One tendril of the vine terminates in a lily-like flower just above and slightly to the right of the figure's head.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, reclines on the ground with his legs extended to the left and perhaps crossed. He props up his upper body with his arms. He holds his head in his left hand in a posture traditionally associated with melancholy. There are no clear indications of clothing. He looks down at what may be a book held by his right forearm and hand.
The long leaves of two plants, or very long grasses, arch over the figure.
A tree grows up the right margin. Its branches and leaves extend horizontally along the top margin of the plate.
A vine is intertwined around the tree near the right margin of the plate. One of the vine's tendrils terminates in a lily-like flower just above and slightly to the right of the figure's head.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 9 (Bentley b4, Erdman b4, Keynes b4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure, apparently male, lies rigidly on his back. There are no clear indications of clothing. His face is turned upwards and his arms are at his side. His head rests on a cushion, pillow, or perhaps even a block of stone. He may be sleeping or dead. Above and to the right of his head is a small figure hovering in the air and facing to the left. His/her legs are spread apart and at least one arm is extended horizontally to the left.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, apparently male, lies rigidly supine. There are no clear indications of clothing. His face is turned upwards and his arms are at his side. Perhaps he is sleeping or dead.

A very small figure hovers above the supine figure's head. He/she faces left, legs spread apart and with at least one arm raised horizontally and extended to the left. This figure may have long hair trailing out to the right.
The supine figure's head rests on a cushion, pillow, or perhaps even a block of stone.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with one loop and perhaps some long leaves fills the space left of the heading number ("II," line 1). Right of the number is a vine or branch with leaves and perhaps a few berries.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine with one loop and perhaps some long leaves fills the space left of the heading number ("II," line 1).
A vine or branch with leaves and perhaps a few berries fills the space right of the heading number ("II," line 1).

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 10 (Bentley b12, Erdman b12, Keynes b12)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, lies supine on a bed of straw (as suggested by the yellow coloring) or—if he is of great size—on hills. His face is turned to his right and thus towards us; his right arm dangles rather limply at his side. There are no clear indications of clothing. Perhaps he is sleeping or dead. Lines of radiance appear around his head. This last motif suggests that this may be Christ, the "God" who "becomes as / we are" (lines 2-3) in the text.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, lies supine on a bed of straw (as suggested by the yellow coloring) or—if he is of great size—on hills. His face is turned to his right and thus towards us; his right arm dangles rather limply at his side. There are no clear indications of clothing. Perhaps he is sleeping or dead. Lines of radiance appear around his head. This last motif suggests that this may be Christ, the "God" who "becomes as / we are" (lines 2-3) in the text.
The figure lies supine on a bed of straw (as suggested by the yellow coloring) or—if he is of great size—on hills.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several vines decorate the spaces on all sides of the first line of text ("Therefore"). A single vine, poorly printed in this copy, appears above the first four letters and descends in three branches to the left of the word. A vine with a single loop and perhaps some leaves grows at the end of the word. Two vines lie beneath the word; the one on the right has a single loop and terminates in three leaves or small flowers. A vine descends in the margin right of the third and fourth lines of text. A vine appears left of the last line of text ("is," line 5). Another vine with two loops descends right of that same line and into the space between the text and the illustration at the bottom of the plate. The vine bears several leaves or small flowers. The last letter of "may" (line 4) bears a vine-like descender.

component.illusobjdesc: A single vine, poorly printed in this copy, appears above the first four letters of "Therefore" (line 1) and descends in three branches to the left of the word.
A vine with a single loop and perhaps long, slender leaves at its termination appears in the margin right of "Therefore" (line 1).
A vine, perhaps with a few small leaves, appears under the first four letters of "Therefore" (line 1).
A vine with a single loop appears beneath and to the right of the last four letters of "Therefore" (line 1). It terminates in three leaves or small flowers.
A vine descends in the margin right of the third and fourth lines of text.
The last letter of "may" (line 4) bears a vine-like descender.
A vine appears left of the last line of text ("is," line 5).

A vine with two loops descends right of the last line of text ("is," line 5) and into the space between the text and the illustration at the bottom of the plate. The vine bears several leaves or small flowers.
